name: Shallot
climate: Shallots thrive in temperate climates with cool and mild winters.
They prefer a climate with temperatures ranging from 55°F to 75°F.
A shallot grows well in climates where summers aren't excessively hot.
They do not do well in high humidity climates or excessive rainfall.
sunlight: Shallots require full sun exposure for the best bulb production.
They need at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day.
Partial shade can result in smaller, less flavorful bulbs.
Shallots thrive in areas where they can get regular full sun light.
watering: Shallots require consistent moisture, especially during bulb formation.
They prefer well-draining soil to avoid waterlogged soil conditions.
Watering should be moderate, about once a week in absence of rain.
Avoid overwatering as shallots are prone to rot in waterlogged soil.
soil: Shallots grow best in loose, well-draining, sandy soil enriched with compost.
A pH range between 6.0 and 7.0 is ideal for shallot growth.
They require fertile soil, rich in organic matter and nutrients.
Heavy, clay soils should be amended with compost to improve drainage.
extra_care_tip: Mulching around shallots can help maintain consistent soil moisture.
Avoid watering the foliage; focus watering at the base to prevent disease.
Crop rotation is advisable to prevent disease buildup in soil.
If leaves yellow prematurely, check for pests or nutrient deficiency.
